    "patch": "@@ -49,21 +49,6 @@ To enable the multi-Geo capability for Microsoft Entra Private Access, complete\n > - Multi-Geo doesn't support the Domain Name System (DNS) experience.\n > - Mulit-Geo doesn't support Japan region selection through Microsoft Entra admin center.   \n \n-## Enable multi-Geo capability for Japan region\n-The UI experience through the Microsoft Entra admin center doesn't support the Japan region yet. To select Japan as **country/region** for the connector group, use Microsoft Graph APIs:\n-- Open Microsoft [Graph Explorer](https://developer.microsoft.com/graph/graph-explorer) and login with the tenant account.\n-- Create a [Connector Group](/graph/api/connectorgroup-post?view=graph-rest-beta&tabs=http&preserve-view=true) using Graph API. Use `region` property to assign the region to Japan. For example, run the `POST` request with region set to `Japan` to create a connector group assigned to Japan.\n-\n-### Example HTTP Request\n-```http\n-POST https://graph.microsoft.com/beta/onPremisesPublishingProfiles/applicationProxy/connectorGroups\n-Content-type: application/json\n-\n-{\n-  \"name\": \"<Connector Group Name>\",\n-  \"region\": \"Japan\"\n-}\n-```\n ## Related content\n \n * [How to configure private network connectors for Microsoft Entra Private Access and Microsoft Entra application proxy](how-to-configure-connectors.md)"

  {
    "sha": "4b7928b5aeb7e07b1320cfef3a50ca29794b610e",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-transport-layer-security-settings.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 100,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 100,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-transport-layer-security-settings.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-transport-layer-security-settings.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-transport-layer-security-settings.md?ref=03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,100 @@\n+---\n+title: Configure Transport Layer Security Inspection Settings (preview)\n+description: Learn how to configure a Transport Layer Security inspection certificate authority\n+author: HULKsmashGithub\n+ms.author: jayrusso\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.topic: how-to \n+ms.reviewer: teresayao\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+\n+\n+#customer intent: As a Global Secure Access administrator, I want to configure a context-aware Transport Layer Security inspection policy and assign the policy to users in my organization.   \n+---\n+\n+# Configure Transport Layer Security inspection settings (preview)\n+Transport Layer Security (TLS) inspection in Microsoft Entra Internet Access uses a two-tier Intermediate certificate model to issue dynamically generated leaf certificates for decrypting traffic. This article explains how to configure the Certificate Authority (CA) that serves as the Global Secure Access intermediate CA, including signing and uploading the certificate.\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> The Transport Layer Security inspection feature is currently in PREVIEW.   \n+> This information relates to a prerelease product that might be substantially modified before release. Microsoft makes no warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to the information provided here.   \n+> While in preview, don't use TLS inspection in production environments.    \n+ \n+\n+\n+## Prerequisites   \n+To complete the steps in this process, you must have the following prerequisites in place:      \n+- A Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) service to sign the Certificate Signing Request (CSR) and generate an intermediate certificate for TLS inspection. For testing scenarios, you can also use a self-signed root certificate created with OpenSSL.   \n+- A trial license for Microsoft Entra Internet Access.  \n+- [Global Secure Access prerequisites](how-to-configure-web-content-filtering.md) \n+\n+### Global Secure Access admin: create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination\n+To create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination:\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/) as a [Global Secure Access Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-secure-access-administrator).\n+1. Browse to **Global Secure Access** > **Secure** > **TLS inspection policies**.\n+1. Switch to the **TLS inspection settings** tab.\n+1. Select **+ Create certificate**. This step starts with generating a Certificate Sign Request (CSR). \n+1. In the **Create certificate** pane, fill in the following fields:\n+   - **Certificate name**: This name appears in the certificate hierarchy when viewed in a browser. It must be unique, contain no spaces, and be no more than 12 characters long. You can't reuse previous names.\n+   - **Common name** (CN): Common name, for example, Contoso TLS ICA, that identifies the intermediate certificate.\n+   - **Organizational Unit** (OU): Organization name, for example, Contoso IT.\n+1. Select **Create CSR**. This step creates a .csr file and saves it to your default download folder.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security-settings/create-certificate.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create certificate pane with fields filled and the Create CSR button highlighted.\":::   \n+\n+1. Sign the CSR using your PKI service. Make sure **Server Auth** is in Extended Key Usage and `certificate authority (CA)=true`, `keyCertSign,cRLSign`, and `basicConstraints=critical,CA:TRUE` in Basic Extension. Save the signed certificate in .pem format. If you're testing with a self-signed certificate, follow the instructions to [use OpenSSL to sign the CSR](#test-with-a-self-signed-root-certificate-authority-using-openssl). \n+   \n+1. Select **+ Upload certificate**.\n+1. In the Upload certificate form, upload the certificate.pem and chain.pem files.\n+1. Select **Upload signed certificate**.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security-settings/upload-certificate.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of Upload certificate form with example certificate and chain certificate files in the upload fields.\"::: \n+\n+1. After the certificate uploads, the status changes to **Active**.  We support **one** Active certificate currently.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security-settings/status-active.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the TLS inspection settings tab with the certificate status set to Active.\":::   \n+\n+\n+### Test with a self-signed root certificate authority using OpenSSL\n+For **testing purposes only**, use a self-signed root certificate authority (CA) that you create with OpenSSL to sign the CSR. \n+1. If you don't already have one, first create an *openssl.cnf* file with this configuration:\n+```ini\n+[ rootCA_ext ]\n+subjectKeyIdentifier = hash\n+authorityKeyIdentifier = keyid:always,issuer\n+basicConstraints = critical, CA:true\n+keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature, cRLSign, keyCertSign\n+\n+[ interCA_ext ]\n+subjectKeyIdentifier = hash\n+authorityKeyIdentifier = keyid:always,issuer\n+basicConstraints = critical, CA:true, pathlen:1\n+keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature, cRLSign, keyCertSign\n+\n+[ signedCA_ext ]\n+basicConstraints = critical, CA:true\n+keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature, cRLSign, keyCertSign\n+extendedKeyUsage = serverAuth\n+\n+[ server_ext ]\n+subjectKeyIdentifier = hash\n+authorityKeyIdentifier = keyid:always,issuer\n+basicConstraints = critical, CA:false\n+keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature\n+extendedKeyUsage = serverAuth\n+```\n+\n+2. Create a new root certificate authority and private key using the following *openssl.cnf* config file:   \n+```openssl req -x509 -new -nodes -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout rootCAchain.key -sha256 -days 370 -out rootCAchain.pem -subj \"/C=US/ST=US/O=Self Signed/CN=Self Signed Root CA\" -config openssl.cnf -extensions rootCA_ext```\n+1. Sign the CSR using the following command:\n+ ```openssl x509 -req -in <CSR file> -CA rootCAchain.pem -CAkey rootCAchain.key -CAcreateserial -out signedcertificate.pem -days 370 -sha256 -extfile openssl.cnf -extensions signedCA_ext```\n+1. Upload the signed certificates (```signedcertificate.pem```and ```rootCAchain.pem```) according to the steps in [Create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination](#global-secure-access-admin-create-a-csr-and-upload-the-signed-certificate-for-tls-termination).\n+\n+### PowerShell examples to configure certificate authority for TLS inspection\n+Examples of configuring TLS certificate using ADCS and OpenSSL can be found in below links: \n+* [Create a TLS certificates using ADCS](scripts/powershell-active-directory-certificate-service.md)\n+* [Create a TLS certificate using OpenSSL](scripts/powershell-open-secure-sockets-layer.md) \n+\n+## Related content\n+* [What is Transport Layer Security inspection?](concept-transport-layer-security.md)\n+* [How to configure Transport Layer Security inspection policy](how-to-transport-layer-security.md)\n+* [Frequently asked questions for Transport Layer Security inspection](faq-transport-layer-security.yml)\n+"
  },

    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-transport-layer-security.md",

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-transport-layer-security.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-transport-layer-security.md?ref=03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad",
    "patch": "@@ -1,19 +1,19 @@\n ---\n-title: Configure Transport Layer Security Inspection (Preview)\n+title: Configure Transport Layer Security Inspection Policies (preview)\n description: Learn how to configure a Transport Layer Security inspection policy and assign it to users in your organization.\n author: HULKsmashGithub\n ms.author: jayrusso\n manager: dougeby\n ms.service: global-secure-access\n ms.topic: how-to \n ms.reviewer: teresayao\n-ms.date: 09/10/2025\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n \n \n #customer intent: As a Global Secure Access administrator, I want to configure a context-aware Transport Layer Security inspection policy and assign the policy to users in my organization.   \n ---\n \n-# Configure Transport Layer Security inspection (Preview)\n+# Configure Transport Layer Security inspection policies (preview)\n Transport Layer Security (TLS) inspection in Microsoft Entra Internet Access lets you decrypt and inspect encrypted traffic at service edge locations. This feature lets Global Secure Access apply advanced security controls like threat detection, content filtering, and granular access policies. These access policies help protect against threats that might be hidden in encrypted communications.\n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n@@ -25,54 +25,29 @@ This article explains how to create a context-aware Transport Layer Security ins\n \n ## Prerequisites   \n To complete the steps in this process, you must have the following prerequisites in place:      \n-- A Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) service to sign the Certificate Signing Request (CSR) and generate an intermediate certificate for TLS inspection. For testing scenarios, you can also use a self-signed root certificate created with OpenSSL.   \n+- Completed TLS inspection settings with an active, enabled certificate authority.   \n - Test devices or virtual machines running Windows that are either Microsoft Entra joined or hybrid joined to your organization's Microsoft Entra ID.  \n - A trial license for Microsoft Entra Internet Access.  \n - [Global Secure Access prerequisites](how-to-configure-web-content-filtering.md) \n \n ## Create a context-aware TLS inspection policy\n To create a context-aware Transport Layer Security inspection policy and assign it to users in your organization, complete the following steps:\n-1. [Create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination](#step-1-global-secure-access-admin-create-a-csr-and-upload-the-signed-certificate-for-tls-termination)\n-1. [Create a TLS inspection policy](#step-2-global-secure-access-admin-create-a-tls-inspection-policy)\n-1. [Link the TLS inspection policy to a security profile](#step-3-global-secure-access-admin-link-the-tls-inspection-policy-to-a-security-profile)\n-1. [Test the configuration](#step-4-test-the-configuration)\n-\n-### Step 1: Global Secure Access admin: create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination\n-To create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination:\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/) as a [Global Secure Access Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-secure-access-administrator).\n-1. Browse to **Global Secure Access** > **Secure** > **TLS inspection policies**.\n-1. Switch to the **TLS inspection settings** tab.\n-1. Select **+ Create certificate**. This step starts with generating a Certificate Sign Request (CSR). \n-1. In the **Create certificate** pane, fill in the following fields:\n-   - **Certificate name**: This name appears in the certificate hierarchy when viewed in a browser. It must be unique, contain no spaces, and be no more than 12 characters long. You can't reuse previous names.\n-   - **Common name** (CN): Common name, for example, Contoso TLS ICA, that identifies the intermediate certificate.\n-   - **Organizational Unit** (OU): Organization name, for example, Contoso IT.\n-1. Select **Create CSR**. This step creates a .csr file and saves it to your default download folder.\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/create-certificate.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create certificate pane with fields filled and the Create CSR button highlighted.\":::   \n-\n-1. Sign the CSR using your PKI service. Make sure Server Auth is in Extended Key Usage and `certificate authority (CA)=true`, `keyCertSign,cRLSign`, and `basicConstraints=critical,CA:TRUE` in Basic Extension. Save the signed certificate in .pem format. If you're testing with a self-signed certificate, follow the instructions to [use OpenSSL to sign the CSR](#test-with-a-self-signed-root-certificate-authority-using-openssl). \n-   \n-1. Select **+Upload certificate**.\n-1. In the Upload certificate form, upload the certificate.pem and chain.pem files.\n-1. Select **Upload signed certificate**.\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/upload-certificate.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of Upload certificate form with example certificate and chain certificate files in the upload fields.\"::: \n-\n-1. After the certificate uploads, the status changes to **Active**.   \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/status-active.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the TLS inspection settings tab with the certificate status set to Active.\":::   \n-\n-For a test configuration, see [Test with a self-signed root certificate authority using OpenSSL](#test-with-a-self-signed-root-certificate-authority-using-openssl).  \n-\n-### Step 2: Global Secure Access admin: create a TLS inspection policy\n+### Step 1: Global Secure Access admin: create a TLS inspection policy\n To create a TLS inspection policy:\n-1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Secure** > **TLS inspection policies**.\n-1. Create a new policy with **Action** set to **Inspect**.   \n-1. Select **Save**. This configuration enables TLS termination for all traffic categories except Education, Finance, Government, and Health and medicine.\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/inspection-policy.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create a TLS inspection policy screen open to the Review tab.\":::   \n+1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Secure** > **TLS inspection policies** > **Create policy**.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/create-tls-inspection-policy.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create a TLS inspection policy screen open to the Basics tab.\":::\n+The **Default action** specifies what to do if no rules match. The default setting is **Inspect**.\n+1.  Select **Next** > **Add rule**. On the **Rules** page, you can define a custom rule by specifying an **FQDN** or selecting a **Web category**.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/add-rule.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create a TLS inspection policy screen open to the Rules tab.\":::\n \n-### Step 3: Global Secure Access admin: link the TLS inspection policy to a security profile\n+1. To complete the policy configuration, go to **Save** > **Next** > **Submit**. Note a system rule has been auto created to exclude destinations that do not work with TLS inspection. An editable recommended bypass rule is automatically created to exclude Education, Finance, Government, and Health & Medicine categories for TLS policies migrating from the preview. \n+1. To review rules, including the auto-created rules, select a policy and then go to **Edit** > **Rules**.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-transport-layer-security/edit-policy-rules.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Edit a TLS inspection policy screen open to the Rules tab.\":::\n+\n+### Step 2: Global Secure Access admin: link the TLS inspection policy to a security profile\n Link the TLS inspection policy to a security profile. \n \n-Before you enable TLS inspection on user traffic, make sure your organization has established and communicated an appropriate Terms of Use (ToU) for end users. This step helps maintain transparency and supports compliance with privacy and consent requirements.\n+Before you enable TLS inspection on user traffic, make sure your organization has established and communicated TLS policy to end users. This step helps maintain transparency and supports compliance with privacy and consent requirements.\n \n You can link the TLS policy to a security profile in two ways:\n #### Option 1: Link the TLS policy to the baseline profile for all users   \n@@ -123,43 +98,8 @@ To disable TLS inspection:\n     1. Select **Actions**.\n     1. Select **Delete**.      \n \n-## Test with a self-signed root certificate authority using OpenSSL\n-For **testing purposes only**, use a self-signed root certificate authority (CA) that you create with OpenSSL to sign the CSR. To test with OpenSSL:\n-1. If you don't already have one, create an *openssl.cnf* file with this configuration:\n-```ini\n-[ rootCA_ext ]\n-subjectKeyIdentifier = hash\n-authorityKeyIdentifier = keyid:always,issuer\n-basicConstraints = critical, CA:true\n-keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature, cRLSign, keyCertSign\n-\n-[ interCA_ext ]\n-subjectKeyIdentifier = hash\n-authorityKeyIdentifier = keyid:always,issuer\n-basicConstraints = critical, CA:true, pathlen:1\n-keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature, cRLSign, keyCertSign\n-\n-[ signedCA_ext ]\n-basicConstraints = critical, CA:true\n-keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature, cRLSign, keyCertSign\n-extendedKeyUsage = serverAuth\n-\n-[ server_ext ]\n-subjectKeyIdentifier = hash\n-authorityKeyIdentifier = keyid:always,issuer\n-basicConstraints = critical, CA:false\n-keyUsage = critical, digitalSignature\n-extendedKeyUsage = serverAuth\n-```\n-\n-2. Create a new root certificate authority and private key using the following *openssl.cnf* config file:   \n-```openssl req -x509 -new -nodes -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout rootCAchain.key -sha256 -days 370 -out rootCAchain.pem -subj \"/C=US/ST=US/O=Self Signed/CN=Self Signed Root CA\" -config openssl.cnf -extensions rootCA_ext```\n-1. Sign the CSR using the following command:\n- ```openssl x509 -req -in <CSR file> -CA rootCAchain.pem -CAkey rootCAchain.key -CAcreateserial -out signedcertificate.pem -days 370 -sha256 -extfile openssl.cnf -extensions signedCA_ext```\n-1. Upload the signed certificates (```signedcertificate.pem```and ```rootCAchain.pem```) according to the steps in [Create a CSR and upload the signed certificate for TLS termination](#step-1-global-secure-access-admin-create-a-csr-and-upload-the-signed-certificate-for-tls-termination).\n-\n-Examples of configuring TLS certificate using powershell are listed in the below related content section.\n ## Related content\n+* [Configure TLS inspection settings](how-to-transport-layer-security-settings.md) \n * [Create a TLS certificates using ADCS](scripts/powershell-active-directory-certificate-service.md)\n * [Create a TLS certificate using OpenSSL](scripts/powershell-open-secure-sockets-layer.md) \n * [What is Transport Layer Security inspection?](concept-transport-layer-security.md)"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -48,7 +48,9 @@ When setting a workflow where the trigger type is **Time based attribute**, the\n |---------|---------|\n |Days from Event     |  The days from the event user attribute for when the workflow is triggered. Value can be from 0-180.     |\n |Event timing     |   Defines when the *Days from Event*  detail for a workflow is triggered. For example, a workflow that is scheduled to run for a user before they start working would have an event timing value of **Before**, while a workflow scheduled to run for a user after they leave your organization would have an event timing value of **After**. If selecting a template for a workflow that runs on the same day as the event user attribute, the value is **On**.      |\n-|Event user attribute     | The attribute defining the change that triggers the workflow. The type of workflow being used determines the attributes available. A joiner workflow can have the attribute value of \"*employeeHireDate*\" or \"*createdDateTime*\", while a leaver workflow has an attribute value of \"*employeeLeaveDate*\" or \"*LastSignInDateTime*\". For a list of templates, and their event user attributes, see: [Lifecycle Workflows templates and categories](lifecycle-workflow-templates.md).       |\n+|Event user attribute     | The attribute defining the change that triggers the workflow. The type of workflow being used determines the attributes available. A joiner workflow can have the attribute value of \"*employeeHireDate*\" or \"*createdDateTime*\", while a leaver workflow has an attribute value of \"*employeeLeaveDate*\" or \"*LastSignInDateTime*\". For a list of templates, and their event user attributes, see: [Lifecycle Workflows templates and categories](lifecycle-workflow-templates.md). You are also able to set custom attribute triggers. For more information, see [Use Custom Attribute Triggers in Lifecycle Workflows (Preview)](workflow-custom-triggers.md).       |\n+\n+\n \n > [!NOTE]\n > The event user attribute must be set within Microsoft Entra ID for users.     "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,100 @@\n+---\n+title: Use custom attribute triggers in lifecycle workflows (Preview)\n+description: This article discusses how to use Custom Attribute Triggers as an attribute change trigger within a workflow in Lifecycle Workflows.\n+author: owinfreyATL\n+ms.author: owinfrey\n+ms.service: entra-id-governance\n+ms.subservice: lifecycle-workflows\n+ms.topic: how-to #Required; leave this attribute/value as-is\n+ms.date: 10/29/2025\n+\n+#CustomerIntent: As a Lifecycle Workflows Administrator, I want to use Custom Attribute triggers as an attribute change trigger so that I can trigger workflows based on other custom attributes.\n+---\n+\n+\n+\n+# Use Custom attribute triggers in lifecycle workflows (Preview)\n+\n+Lifecycle Workflows allows you to trigger workflows to run automatically for users that meet the execution conditions of the workflow. There are many default attributes that you can use to trigger workflows, but sometimes you might require triggering a workflow based on a specific attribute not offered by default. Using custom attribute triggers, you can trigger a workflow to run for users based on when they move within your organization based on:\n+\n+- [Custom security attributes (CSA)](manage-workflow-custom-security-attribute.md)\n+- Directory extension attributes\n+- On-premises extension attributes (1-15)\n+- EmployeeOrgData attributes\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [Microsoft Entra ID Governance license](../includes/entra-entra-governance-license.md)]\n+\n+\n+## Use custom attribute triggers in a new workflow using the Microsoft Entra admin center\n+\n+To use custom attribute triggers in a new workflow, do the following steps:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Lifecycle Workflows Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#lifecycle-workflows-administrator) and [Attribute Assignment Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#attribute-assignment-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Lifecycle workflows** > **Create a workflow**.\n+\n+1. On the Workflows page, select a workflow template that you want to use a custom security attribute as part of the scope for.\n+\n+1. Enter the basic information such as display name, description, and administration scope.\n+\n+1. Under **Trigger type** select **Attribute changes**.\n+\n+1. For Attribute, select the attribute trigger you want to trigger the workflow to run. \n+\n+1. Finish configuring the workflow and save it.  \n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Attribute changes are only detected for scheduled workflows.\n+\n+## Add a custom attribute to an existing workflow trigger using the Microsoft Entra admin center\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Lifecycle Workflows Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#lifecycle-workflows-administrator) and [Attribute Assignment Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#attribute-assignment-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Lifecycle workflows** > **workflows**.\n+    \n+1. Select the workflow that you want to add a custom attribute to the trigger of.\n+\n+1. On the workflow overview page, select **Execution conditions**.\n+\n+1. Under **Trigger details**, update the trigger with the custom attribute you want to use to trigger the workflow.\n+\n+1. Select **Save**.\n+\n+\n+## Custom attribute trigger considerations\n+\n+Currently the workflow and the workflow schedule must be enabled for attributes changes to be picked up and workflows executions to be scheduled. Once Lifecycle Workflows starts checking for attribute changes, the time it takes for changes to be picked up might be delayed for these custom attributes. While changes should be picked up within minutes, there are upstream processes that will add further delays after the user attribute changes, for example:\n+- Custom attributes might take up to 4 hours for their changes to be updated by the underlying service, however, once the custom attributes changes are propagated, Lifecycle Workflows should pick up the change within seconds.\n+- Once changes are picked up by Lifecycle workflows, workflow execution will occur in the next target run, according to the schedule for users that meet the workflow scope.\n+\n+## Attribute vs custom attribute processing timing\n+\n+The following image shows the potential differences in processing times for using regular attributes and custom attributes in the workflow trigger. \n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/workflow-custom-triggers/custom-attribute-timing.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a comparison between regular and custom attribute processing timing in a workflow run.\":::\n+\n+\n+In example A, The workflow is scheduled to run when the department attribute changes, it's 12:00 pm and the next target runs are at 1pm and 2pm:\n+- At 12:10pm, the user department changes\n+- At 12:15 pm, the user is detected to be in scope of the workflow\n+- In the 1pm run, the user gets processed by the workflow\n+\n+\n+In example B, Workflow is scheduled to run when the TestCustomSecurityAttribute1 attribute changes, it's 12:00 pm and the next target runs are at 1pm and 2pm:\n+- At 12:10pm the TestCustomSecurityAttribute1 attribute changes for a user\n+- At 3:55 pm the change is passed to Lifecycle Workflows\n+- At 4:00 pm the user is detected to be in scope of the workflow (too late for the 4pm run)\n+- In the 5pm run, the user gets processed by the workflow\n+\n+For frequently asked question about using custom attribute triggers within lifecycle workflows, see: [Lifecycle workflows FAQs](workflows-faqs.md).\n+\n+\n+\n+## Next step\n+\n+- [Lifecycle workflows execution conditions and scheduling](lifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md)\n+- [Custom security attributes (CSA)](manage-workflow-custom-security-attribute.md)\n+\n+\n+"
  },
  {
    "sha": "0e5988f299227186b01c36ae34054bdf60cf157b",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/workflows-faqs.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 17,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 17,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fworkflows-faqs.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fworkflows-faqs.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fworkflows-faqs.md?ref=03a276baeb24eb2d9a06dd6f0b031e40e4cc08ad",
    "patch": "@@ -58,6 +58,23 @@ Lifecycle workflows checks that the user is assigned the custom security attribu\n \n If a user is assigned a custom security attribute that has multiple values, and one of the values matches the value in the specified in rule expressions, the user matches the scope.\n \n+### Why can’t I see the custom attributes listed in the attributes change trigger?\n+\n+To see the expected attributes in the drop down list, you need to ensure the following:\n+\n+- The attributes must be configured and active\n+- For custom security attributes, you have the appropriate permissions\n+\n+\n+### Do workflows using custom attribute triggers always take 4 hours to process changes?\n+\n+No, the change processing time can vary depending on tenant change activity, timing and volume, with 4 hours expected to be the upper limit. We are working to optimize the timing as much as possible in hopes of reducing the time it takes.\n+\n+\n+### What happens if I have multiple workflows using custom attributes as triggers?\n+\n+If multiple workflows are using the same custom attribute as trigger, when that change is processed, those workflows will be processed at the same time. If multiple workflows are using different custom attributes as trigger, but the custom attributes updates occurred at the same time, then those workflows will be processed at the same time. If the attribute updates occur at different times, then the workflows processing may be different.\n+\n ## Next steps\n \n - [What are Lifecycle workflows?](what-are-lifecycle-workflows.md)"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit updates documentation for Microsoft Entra Global Secure Access and ID Governance. Key changes include the removal of instructions for manually enabling multi-geo for the Japan region in Global Secure Access, along with the addition of a new article detailing how to configure Transport Layer Security (TLS) inspection settings. Within the ID Governance documentation, new content has been introduced to explain how to utilise custom attribute triggers for Lifecycle Workflows, along with updates to the FAQ section addressing custom attribute processing times and multiple workflow triggers.

  "sha": "78c55f5b18aa51de9e295e067c969c4ea699905f",
  "filename": "docs/architecture/backup-authentication-system.md",
  "status": "modified",
  "additions": 4,
  "deletions": 0,
  "changes": 4,
  "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/84d7a7148789eee22e8669d6624fea1022994c0e/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fbackup-authentication-system.md",
  "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/84d7a7148789eee22e8669d6624fea1022994c0e/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fbackup-authentication-system.md",
  "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fbackup-authentication-system.md?ref=84d7a7148789eee22e8669d6624fea1022994c0e",
  "patch": "@@ -72,6 +72,10 @@ Certain other types of policies don't support use of the backup authentication s\n - Use of the [authentication methods policy](~/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-grant.md#require-authentication-strength).\n - Use of [classic Conditional Access policies](~/identity/conditional-access/policy-migration-mfa.md).\n \n+#### Evaluation of report-only Conditional Access policies\n+\n+If a request is processed by the backup authentication system, report-only Conditional Access policies will appear under the **Conditional Access** tab in **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Sign-in logs** for that sign-in event, rather than in the **Report-only** tab. Note that even in this view, policies configured in report-only mode are never enforced. To see if tokens were issued via backup authentication system within your tenant, you can use the sign-in logs. In **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Sign-in Logs**, add the filter `Token issuer type == Microsoft Entra Backup Auth` to display the logs processed by the backup authentication system. \n+\n ### Certificate revocation and the backup authentication system \n \n To enhance its resilience posture, the backup authentication system can't perform fresh revocation checks. Instead, it relies on the state of the certificate revocation list (CRL) check that's performed when the session was last backed up. If you need to revoke before this backup expires, you should explicitly revoke the session instead of waiting for the CRL.  "
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: The changes update the documentation for the backup authentication system. A new section has been added detailing the evaluation of report-only Conditional Access policies when processed by the backup authentication system. It clarifies that these policies will appear in the 'Conditional Access' tab of sign-in logs, not the 'Report-only' tab, and explains how to filter sign-in logs to identify events processed by the backup authentication system.

Continued ADAL usage bypasses modern security protections available only in MSAL, including Conditional Access enforcement, Continuous Access Evaluation (CAE), and advanced token protection. ADAL applications create security vulnerabilities by using weaker legacy authentication patterns, often calling deprecated Azure AD Graph endpoints, and preventing adoption of hardened authentication flows that could mitigate future security advisories. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Migrate applications to the Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL)](/entra/identity-platform/msal-migration)" }, { "sha": "740462f8225027712b962f8b212350770fcb12af", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21781.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21781.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21781.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21781.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -7,6 +7,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 02/03/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Monitor and detect cyberthreats\n # 21781, 21782, 21783 are the same content. Excessive Global Administrator assignments create multiple high-value targets for threat actors who might leverage initial access through credential compromise, phishing attacks, or insider threats to gain unrestricted access to the entire Microsoft Entra ID tenant and connected Microsoft 365 services. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Minimize the number of Global Administrator role assignments](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/best-practices#5-limit-the-number-of-global-administrators-to-less-than-5)" }, { "sha": "bb8d4126fbfb892972822ac96c950268ecbbc923", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21814.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21814.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21814.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21814.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -7,6 +7,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 02/03/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n # sfipillar: Protect engineering systems\n # category: Devices\n # risklevel: High" }, { "sha": "aa1d6d0043c5a36ad6c896f445ecb054620312a6", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21839.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 10/10/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Credential management\n # risklevel: High" }, { "sha": "00c603fb8f141f9ef8318ad1fa43674712accced", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21840.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21840.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21840.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21840.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Security key attestation is enforced\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/23/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+When security key attestation isn't enforced, threat actors can exploit weak or compromised authentication hardware to establish persistent presence within organizational environments. Without attestation validation, malicious actors can register unauthorized or counterfeit FIDO2 security keys that bypass hardware-backed security controls, enabling them to perform credential stuffing attacks using fabricated authenticators that mimic legitimate security keys. This initial access lets threat actors escalate privileges by using the trusted nature of hardware authentication methods, then move laterally through the environment by registering more compromised security keys on high-privilege accounts. The lack of attestation enforcement creates a pathway for threat actors to establish command and control through persistent hardware-based authentication methods, ultimately leading to data exfiltration or system compromise while maintaining the appearance of legitimate hardware-secured authentication throughout the attack chain. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Enable attestation enforcement through the Authentication methods policy configuration](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2#enable-passkey-fido2-authentication-method).\n+- [Configure approved list of security keys by Authenticator Attestation Globally Unique Identifier (AAGUID)](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-fido2-hardware-vendor)." }, { "sha": "66d3f4561476feff3cf44a69e5a038a4d149fe53", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21841.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 10/09/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Credential management\n # risklevel: Medium" }, { "sha": "052b8d51286120c5744ca5c090c82dd0c91e5a5b", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21842.md", "status": "added", "additions": 22, "deletions": 0, "changes": 22, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21842.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21842.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21842.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@\n+---\n+title: Block administrators from using SSPR \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/23/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management, Privileged access\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Self-Service Password Reset (SSPR) for administrators allows password changes to happen without strong secondary authentication factors or administrative oversight. Threat actors who compromise administrative credentials can use this capability to bypass other security controls and maintain persistent access to the environment.\n+\n+Once compromised, attackers can immediately reset the password to lock out legitimate administrators. They can then establish persistence, escalate privileges, and deploy malicious payloads undetected.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Disable SSPR for administrators by updating the authorization policy](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-sspr-policy#administrator-reset-policy-differences) " }, { "sha": "c6386b7a4dbbec0c80d94c258497f26280f65dce", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21844.md", "status": "added", "additions": 22, "deletions": 0, "changes": 22, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21844.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21844.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21844.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@\n+---\n+title: Block legacy Azure AD PowerShell module\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Access control\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Threat actors frequently target legacy management interfaces such as the Azure AD PowerShell module (AzureAD and AzureADPreview), which don't support modern authentication, Conditional Access enforcement, or advanced audit logging. Continued use of these modules exposes the environment to risks including weak authentication, bypass of security controls, and incomplete visibility into administrative actions. Attackers can exploit these weaknesses to gain unauthorized access, escalate privileges, and perform malicious changes. \n+\n+Block the Azure AD PowerShell module and enforce the use of Microsoft Graph PowerShell or Microsoft Entra PowerShell to ensure that only secure, supported, and auditable management channels are available, which closes critical gaps in the attack chain. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Disable user sign-in for application](/entra/identity/enterprise-apps/disable-user-sign-in-portal)" }, { "sha": "e2a75551902dc13395575bb66e7e640c5f96d030", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21845.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 10/09/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Credential management\n # risklevel: Medium" }, { "sha": "78b3aa0d6fe58ecdc0094f0f68fa5b85ab1fcc49", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21846.md", "status": "added", "additions": 20, "deletions": 0, "changes": 20, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21846.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21846.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21846.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@\n+---\n+title: Restrict Temporary Access Pass to Single Use\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/27/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+When Temporary Access Pass (TAP) is configured to allow multiple uses, threat actors who compromise the credential can reuse it repeatedly during its validity period, extending their unauthorized access window beyond the intended single bootstrapping event. This situation creates an extended opportunity for threat actors to establish persistence by registering additional strong authentication methods under the compromised account during the credential lifetime. A reusable TAP that falls into the wrong hands lets threat actors conduct reconnaissance activities across multiple sessions, gradually mapping the environment and identifying high-value targets while maintaining legitimate-looking access patterns. The compromised TAP can also serve as a reliable backdoor mechanism, allowing threat actors to maintain access even if other compromised credentials are detected and revoked, since the TAP appears as a legitimate administrative tool in security logs.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure Temporary Access Pass for one-time use in authentication methods policy](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-authentication-temporary-access-pass#enable-the-temporary-access-pass-policy) " }, { "sha": "2375f6d8983f4abf2988233777cffcda0751ac79", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21847.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21847.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21847.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21847.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 08/19/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Credential management\n # risklevel: High" }, { "sha": "518206ca8af9c210f5cad1ca05b50d3189741e33", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21848.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 10/09/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Credential management\n # risklevel: Medium" }, { "sha": "be31378bbb0f8f35f0275df33c575a2cc42956e6", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21849.md", "status": "added", "additions": 20, "deletions": 0, "changes": 20, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21849.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21849.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21849.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@\n+---\n+title: Smart lockout duration is set to a minimum of 60 \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/27/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+When Smart Lockout duration is configured below the default 60 seconds, threat actors can exploit shortened lockout periods to conduct password spray and credential stuffing attacks more effectively. Reduced lockout windows allow attackers to resume authentication attempts more rapidly, increasing their success probability while potentially evading detection systems that rely on longer observation periods. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Set Smart Lockout duration to 60 seconds or higher](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-password-smart-lockout#manage-microsoft-entra-smart-lockout-values)" }, { "sha": "7b6bd21972d1ed493d8c8fc24d04430cb6fdaa34", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21850.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 10/07/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # Microsoft Entra ID Protection monitors these identities for suspicious activities like leaked credentials, anomalous API traffic, and malicious applications. Unaddressed risky workload identities enable privilege escalation, lateral movement, data exfiltration, and persistent backdoors that bypass traditional security controls. Organizations must systematically investigate and remediate these risks to prevent unauthorized access. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Investigate and remediate risky workload identities](/entra/id-protection/concept-workload-identity-risk#investigate-risky-workload-identities)\n+- [Apply Conditional Access policies for workload identities](/entra/identity/conditional-access/workload-identity)" }, { "sha": "5afd3d33578d7276b3e0713b62dd6e005ee092b2", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21863.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21863.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21863.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21863.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -7,6 +7,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 03/05/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P2\n # sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n # category: External collaboration\n # risklevel: Medium" }, { "sha": "92667c41d514608fc4ff9fb9526bcf1e7f66b3de", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21875.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21875.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21875.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21875.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: All entitlement management assignment policies that apply to external users require connected organizations \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P2, Governance\n+# sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+# category: External collaboration\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Access packages configured to allow \"All users\" instead of specific connected organizations expose your organization to uncontrolled external access. Threat actors can exploit this by requesting access through compromised external accounts from unauthorized organizations, bypassing the principle of least privilege. This enables initial access, reconnaissance, privilege escalation, and lateral movement within your environment. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Define trusted organizations as connected organizations](/entra/id-governance/entitlement-management-organization#view-the-list-of-connected-organizations)\n+- [Configure access packages to only allow specific connected organizations](/entra/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-package-create#allow-users-not-in-your-directory-to-request-the-access-package)" }, { "sha": "bf47da75524b17436eea9ceef4e5ecdc0e69842b", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21877.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21877.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21877.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21877.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 07/07/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n # sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n # category: Application management \n # risklevel: Medium" }, { "sha": "4928350b78d3a517309f2b2879f8f91d297207f2", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21878.md", "status": "added", "additions": 20, "deletions": 0, "changes": 20, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21878.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21878.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21878.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@\n+---\n+title: All entitlement management policies have an expiration date \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P2, Governance\n+# sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+# category: Identity governance\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Entitlement management policies without expiration dates create persistent access that threat actors can exploit. When user assignments lack time bounds, compromised credentials maintain indefinite access, enabling attackers to establish persistence, escalate privileges through additional access packages, and conduct long-term malicious activities while remaining undetected. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure expiration settings for access packages](/entra/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-package-lifecycle-policy#specify-a-lifecycle)\n\\ No newline at end of file" }, { "sha": "dd928b3ba246d35a4a54d5e9f861e29b27b76331", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21883.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21883.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21883.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21883.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -7,6 +7,7 @@ ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 06/16/2025\n manager: dougeby\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Workload\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Access control\n # risklevel: Low" }, { "sha": "ff36c3ea63e47c0b0ebcb988d04ce67f810d5f12", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21896.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21896.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21896.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21896.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Service principals don't have certificates or credentials associated with them \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Application management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Service principals without proper authentication credentials (certificates or client secrets) create security vulnerabilities that allow threat actors to impersonate these identities. This can lead to unauthorized access, lateral movement within your environment, privilege escalation, and persistent access that's difficult to detect and remediate. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- For your organization's service principals: [Add certificates or client secrets to the app registration](/entra/identity-platform/how-to-add-credentials)\n+- For external service principals: Review and remove any unnecessary credentials to reduce security risk" }, { "sha": "277b9470df1496e2022fa7629f5ac232ad63d699", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21929.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21929.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21929.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21929.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: All entitlement management packages that apply to guests have expirations or access reviews configured in their assignment policies\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P2, Governance\n+# sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+# category: Identity governance\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Access packages for guest users without expiration dates or access reviews allow indefinite access to organizational resources. Compromised or stale guest accounts enable threat actors to maintain persistent, undetected access for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and data exfiltration. Without periodic validation, organizations cannot identify when business relationships change or when guest access is no longer needed. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure lifecycle settings](/entra/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-package-lifecycle-policy)\n+- [Configure access reviews](/entra/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-reviews-create)" }, { "sha": "ef0717ce1fe97661c1a23955dcbc89faa77f5992", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21953.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 10/07/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n # category: Devices\n # risklevel: High" }, { "sha": "1af39fce3d036fa3a4b485760665424ad7ca344f", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21955.md", "status": "added", "additions": 20, "deletions": 0, "changes": 20, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21955.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21955.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21955.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@\n+---\n+title: Manage the local administrators on Microsoft Entra joined devices \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/27/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n+# sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+# category: Devices\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+When local administrators on Microsoft Entra joined devices aren't properly managed, threat actors with compromised credentials can execute device takeover attacks by removing organizational administrators and disabling the device's connection to Microsoft Entra. This lack of control results in complete loss of organizational control, creating orphaned assets that can't be managed or recovered.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Manage the local administrators on Microsoft Entra joined devices](/entra/identity/devices/assign-local-admin#manage-the-microsoft-entra-joined-device-local-administrator-role)" }, { "sha": "06173a3c2a652362b1e8aab7163c50bd7ec31f28", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21985.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 0, "changes": 1, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21985.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21985.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21985.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n ms.date: 06/27/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: P1\n # sfipillar: Protect engineering systems\n # 21885, 23183 are similar content.\n # category: Application management" }, { "sha": "d16b0ab263646c53c9a3436810877470cc58e4d5", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/24570.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F24570.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F24570.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F24570.md?ref=5c64f707f390579f5e1547cc1f5c41fc3315f358", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Entra Connect Sync is configured with Service Principal Credentials \n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/28/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# minimumlicense: Free\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Hybrid infrastructure\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Microsoft Entra Connect Sync using user accounts instead of service principals creates security vulnerabilities. Legacy user account authentication with passwords is more susceptible to credential theft and password attacks than service principal authentication with certificates. Compromised connector accounts allow threat actors to manipulate identity synchronization, create backdoor accounts, escalate privileges, or disrupt hybrid identity infrastructure. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure service principal authentication for Entra Connect](/entra/identity/hybrid/connect/authenticate-application-id?tabs=default#onboard-to-application-based-authentication)\n+- [Remove legacy Directory Synchronization Accounts](/entra/identity/hybrid/connect/authenticate-application-id?tabs=default#remove-a-legacy-service-account)" } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit addresses security configurations and recommendations within Microsoft Entra ID. It updates documentation to reflect license changes for various security checks, making many features available without specific premium licenses. Additionally, several new security recommendations and best practices have been introduced, focusing on areas like workload identity security, temporary access pass usage, and the blocking of legacy PowerShell modules. The changes also refine existing security recommendations related to service principals and entitlement management.

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fbackup-authentication-system.md?ref=7dc3f58ba1f3e0504b504807003bcc8b8e20cce8",
    "patch": "@@ -72,7 +72,7 @@ Certain other types of policies don't support use of the backup authentication s\n - Use of the [authentication methods policy](~/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-grant.md#require-authentication-strength).\n - Use of [classic Conditional Access policies](~/identity/conditional-access/policy-migration-mfa.md).\n \n-### How does certificate revocation work in an outage? \n+### Certificate revocation and the backup authentication system \n \n To enhance its resilience posture, the backup authentication system can't perform fresh revocation checks. Instead, it relies on the state of the certificate revocation list (CRL) check that's performed when the session was last backed up. If you need to revoke before this backup expires, you should explicitly revoke the session instead of waiting for the CRL.  \n "

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates two documentation files. Firstly, it amends a heading in "backup-authentication-system.md" for clarity regarding certificate revocation. Secondly, it adds a clarification to "how-to-connect-install-prerequisites.md" about hardware specifications, specifying that listed requirements are for a combined server and that a remote SQL Server will have its own resource needs.
